rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of urban form through planning administration with special reference to Oromocto, N.B.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Through the centuries, urban form has developed in both a planned and a spontaneous way. In the Greek, Roman, Renaissance and Baroque periods there were some planned towns but the majority developed without following a predetermined pattern. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Architecture
City planning -- Canada
City planning -- New Brunswick -- Oromocto

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The air navigation commission of the international civil aviation organization : study of its functions and powers and an outline of its main fields of activity
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: When man first conquered the air, only a few could foresee all the implications involved in such an act. Within less than half a century, flight became as common as any other medium of transportation, with almost unlimited potentialities. The aircraft became capable of spanning continents and oceans in a matter of hours, reaching every spot on the globe. Geographical distance had shrunk until few areas remained inaccessible. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: International Air Law

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The role of cofactors in the enzymatic reduction of tetrazolium salts by amines
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Aqueous suspensions of rat liver and brain can catalyze the enzymatic reduction of tetrazolium salts by monoamine oxidase preparations; this reaction requires a heat-stable, dialyzable factor(s) found in a variety of animal tissues and yeast.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Epiphenomenalism, a conflict of science and philosophy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For a long time now, I have been thinking about the problem of body and mind and about the strangely wonderful phenomenon of consciousness. The concept of consciousness has always been a relatively neglected topic. As for questions about body and mind, one's first reaction is inevitably the impatient exclamation "But there is no problem there at all." [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Science
Philosophy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An experimental study of noise processes in an electron gun
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An experimental investigation was made of the noise properties of a parallel-flow diode electron gun over the frequency range 200 Mc/s to 3000 Mc/s. Measurements were made at beam voltages from 100 to 1000 volts. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geology of Dungannon and Mayo townships in Southeastern Ontario
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The subject matter of this thesis comprises a geological study of the map area of Dungannon and Mayo townships in southeastern Ontario plus detailed studies of special features of the geology of the map area. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The fluorimetric measurement of adrenaline and noradrenaline in human plasma
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The earliest observations that the adrenal medulla produces a substance which is added to the blood stream and has powerful effects on muscular tissue in general, expecially the heart and vascular system, were made by Oliver and Schafer in 1895, (1). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The root maggots associated with rutabagas in Prince Edward Island: with special attention to the seasonal history and control of the cabbage maggot (Hylemya Brassicae) (Bouche : Diptera, Anthomyiidae)
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Root maggots attacking cruciferous crops were prevalent in Europe during the early part of the nineteenth century. One of the most serious of these pests, the cabbage root maggot, Hylemya brassicae (Bouch√©), was first reported in 1829 in England and it was first found in North America in the Boston area, U.S.A., in 1835. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Age period changes in the composition of the aortic wall in the rabbit
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Due in large measure to various medical advances and discoveries, modern man enjoys a prospect in longevity unknown to his forebears. This has led to an ever-increasing proportion of middle-aged and elderly individuals in our population. It is already apparent that this enlarging group of people is liable to certain diseases either unknown or at least less common in younger groups. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The condensation of B-aminocrotononitrile with cyclohexanones
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Hydrolysis of the cyano groups to carboxyl groups, followed by esterification, would result in the formation of 3,5-dicarbethoxyl derivatives of (LV). It was felt that these derivatives might exhibit pharmacologic activity as local anaesthetics. Demerol is an example of a piperidine derivative which is used as an analgesic. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some factors affecting the relationship between prejudice and the ability to identify ethnic group membership
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One of the most popular ideas in modern experimental psychology is that a person's needs and attitudes influence his perceptions. Yet the more closely we examine the exact nature of any relationship between motivation and perception, the more controversial that relationship becomes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Antipathies and prejudices
Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The geology of the Ste. Justine map-area
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Following the discovery of copper-nickel mineralization in 1951 at St. Fabien de Panet, Montmagny County, about 50 miles east of Quebec City, the Quebec Department of Mines initiated a program of geological mapping in this area. In 1952, the author assisted Dr. J. Beland in the mapping of the St. Magloire area where the copper-nickel mineralization was discovered. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Stark effect under high resolution
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Contrary to available texts on the subject, a surprisingly low external electric field is commonly sufficient to induce new combination lines in the visible spectrum of helium. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Requirements of a lancefield group a streptococcus for growth and nephrotoxin production
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: That all elements which are part of living organisms must be present in their environment, if they shall be in a position to propogate, is axiomatic. However the form in which these elements are useful for the building of cells, differs widely for various organisms. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology & Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Radiative transfer theory and the radiance of the Horizon sky
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The investigation of the atmosphere by optical means has recently received new impetus as a result of the work of S. Chandrasekhar. As a by-product of his work in astrophysics, Chandrasekhar (1950) gave us the solution of one of the fundamental problems of atmospheric optics, that of describing the radiation field which arises from the scattering of sunlight. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the adrenaline-sensitive component of the reticular activating system
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Activation or "arousal" of the EEG is ordinarily thought to be brought about by stimulation, usually by various sensory modalities, of the reticular activating system; this in turn exerts a diffuse influence upon the electrical activity recorded from the entire cortex (Magoun, 1955). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology & Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Disintegration rate determination by 4 counting
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The type of radiation observed to be emitted in a nuclear transition is related to the lifetime of the initial state, from which the transition occurs. Both are dependent on the change of angular momentum and parity, and on the energy available, from the transition between the initial and final states. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Acanthocephala of seals at the Magdalen Islands
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Seals and fish of some parts of the Gulf of St. Lawrence are frequently, and sometimes heavily infected with Acanthocephala of the genus Corynosoma. The present knowledge of this genus in north-eastern American mammals is incomplete and in some cases inaccurate. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Parasitology

rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis is a description of the geology of 125 square miles in south central Newfoundland. The area is a portion of a concession held by the Newfoundland and Labrador Exploration Company, for whom the survey was undertaken. It was mapped by the author and assistants during the summer of 1954. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An analyser for velocity modulated electron beams
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An analyser for the examination of velocity modulated electron beams has been designed and built. The analysis was achieved by displaying on a fluorescent screen the density and velocity variations in the electron stream at a particular point along the beam. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Failure mechanism of steel stressed in triaxial tension
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The occurrence of brittle fracture in steel has been known for many years and has been of direct concern to the engineering profession. In the last twenty years major failures of this type have occurred in a considerable number of important engineering structures and in a very large number of welded steel ships. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering & Applied Mechanics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cytology and correlated morphology of the Genus Neodiprion Rohwer (Hymenoptera: Symphyta)
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Sawflies, as relatively primitive members of the highly specialized order Hymenoptera, have always been regarded with interest. Trends towards parasitism and social habits have been viewed as thought-provoking links to the parasites and ever-popular grouping of bees, ants and wasps. [...]

Sawflies

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Web stresses in a prestressed concrete I-beam
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the comparatively new field of prestressed concrete design, many problems still await investigation. Web stresses in I-shaped prestressed concrete beams are of some importance in stirrup design, but little is known about their actual magnitude and direction. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Applications and limitations of bacteriophage in inducing antigenic and morphological changes in salmonellae
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Since the pioneer work of Bruce White (1926) and the adoption of the Kauffmann-White Antigenic Schema in 1934, the number of Salmonella serotypes has increased tremendously. At the time of writing, the number of recognized types is 363. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology & Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Particular aspects of the Rome convention 1952 on damages at the surface
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study is primarily concerned with the historical development of legal remedies for surface damages caused by foreign aircraft. Progress has been made since the early days of aviation law and it has been my pleasure to reflect upon the studies, proposals, drafts, and conventions in this field prepared by the legal men of our century.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: International Air Law
